channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venezuelan President Targeted by Drone Attack, Officials Say
item.media:description: Security personnel surrounded the Venezuelan president, Nicolás Maduro, after an explosion interrupted a speech he was giving in Caracas on Saturday.
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro was unharmed as explosions caused chaos at a military event being shown on live TV.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: South Africa Vows to End Corruption. Are Its New Leaders Part of the Problem?
item.media:description: Students praying before the start of classes at Mpumelelo Primary School, the site of protests last year.
item.description: The spectacular climb of David Mabuza, the country’s new deputy president, included siphoning off money from schools and other public services to amass enormous power, officials say.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and SELAM GEBREKIDAN

item.title: Aiming for the Stars, and a Chunk of Rock, in Senegal
item.media:description: Outside Dakar, people got a look at the heavens last week through one of the New Horizons space program’s telescopes.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: On a mission to improve science education, the country got a lift with the arrival of an international team of astronomers viewing the far reaches of space.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: A North Korean Defector’s Tale of Lies, Blackmail and Betrayal
item.media:description: Heo Kang-il, a North Korean defector, in Seoul this month. “I wish I could turn the clock back,” he says of his 2016 defection to South Korea with 12 waitresses, who he says he tricked into coming with him.
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.description: A restaurant manager who brought 12 North Korean waitresses to the South says he tricked them — and that South Korean spies tricked him, too. “I wish I could turn the clock back,” he says.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Protests Pop Up Across Iran, Fueled by Daily Dissatisfaction
item.media:description: Shops closed in the grand bazaar in Tehran were closed during a protest in June.
item.media:credit: Iranian Labor News Agency, ILNA, via Associated Press
item.description: While the government is not threatened, more demonstrators have been expressing anger on the streets, and they are not complaining about America.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Orders Retaliatory Sanctions Against American Officials
item.media:description: “We have never bowed our heads,” said President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, seen here on Friday.
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As negotiations fail over the release of the American pastor Andrew Brunson, United States-Turkish relations deteriorate further.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Are ISIS Fighters Prisoners or Honored Guests of the Afghan Government?
item.media:description: More than 250 Islamic State fighters turned themselves in to the Afghan government to avoid imminent capture by Taliban insurgents. About 100 were younger than 18, Afghan officials said.
item.description: Targeted by the Taliban in northern Afghanistan, the Islamic State militants turned themselves into the government, but many civilians are furious at what they see as lenient treatment.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: An Ancient River in Syria Sections Off a Modern War
item.media:description: The near side of the Euphrates River near Manbij, Syria, is controlled by American-backed Kurdish-led forces. On the other side are Turkish-backed Arab rebels.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: A trip along the Euphrates reveals damaged and depopulated towns, and an uneasy front held by a tenuous American presence.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Student Protesters Clash With Police in Bangladesh
item.media:description: Bangladeshi students shouted slogan and blocked roads during a rally demanding safe roads in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Saturday.
item.description: Police in Dhaka fired tear gas and used batons on Saturday to disperse hundreds of protesting students.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Isn’t Holding Up Its End of Nuclear Deal, North Korean Envoy Charges
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo exchanged smiles with Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho of North Korea in Singapore on Saturday. But both men had sharp words about North Korea’s nuclear program during the conference.
item.description: Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho warned that Pyongyang would not start denuclearizing unless Washington took reciprocal actions.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Argentina Group Identifies 128th Person Taken During ‘Dirty War’
item.media:description: Estela de Carlotto, center right, president of Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo, announced the 128th identification of a person snatched during the country’s “dirty war” at a news conference in Buenos Aires on Friday.
item.description: DNA tests have determined the identity of a man taken from his mother as a baby by the former dictatorship, Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo (Argentina)

item.title: Scorching Summer in Europe Signals Long-Term Climate Changes
item.media:description: People trying to cool down in the Trocadero Fountain in front of the Eiffel Tower in Paris.
item.description: Hot weather has touched all of the continent, but it has had the most impact in northern countries, unaccustomed to sustained heat, suggesting that hard years lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Imran Khan’s First Test: Pakistan’s Troubled Economy
item.media:description: Pakistani economists say that Imran Khan, once he becomes prime minister, will have no choice but to ask the International Monetary Fund for a bailout.
item.description: Mr. Khan has promised to improve the country’s economic fortunes, but Pakistan is torn between two financial powers: China and the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: The Great Miss on Climate Change: the Canada Letter
item.media:description: A wildfire burned last month on a mountain in the distance east of Cache Creek, British Columbia.
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The world came close to a solution for climate change 30 years ago but it dropped the ball.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Saudis Deny Role in Attacks That Killed Civilians in Yemeni Port
item.media:description: The death toll after attacks in the port city of Al Hudaydah, Yemen, on Thursday increased to at least 55 people, the Red Cross said Friday. A Saudi-led coalition denied responsibility for the attacks and blamed the Houthi rebels who control the port.
item.description: The Red Cross said strikes on Al Hudaydah left 55 people dead, nearly double the initial tally reported Thursday. The Saudi-led coalition blamed the Houthis.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Jobs, Tariffs, Syria: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Bags of Cash in Argentina: Driver’s Notes Propel Corruption Inquiry
item.media:description: Police officers in Olivos, Argentina, outside the house of Oscar Centeno, a driver at the center of a corruption investigation.
item.description: A man’s decision to cooperate with prosecutors in a case that has already resulted in the arrests of 16 people could be a turning point for corruption investigations in Argentina.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Opposition Calls Vote Results ‘Fraudulent’ in Tense Aftermath
item.media:description: The police tried to break up a news conference for the opposition leader Nelson Chamisa. The event was eventually allowed to continue.
item.description: Street violence subsided but political clashes continued. President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s victory became official, but his opponent, Nelson Chamisa, still insists he won.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Rick Genest, Tattooed Model Known as Zombie Boy, Dies at 32
item.media:description: Rick Genest, who was known as Zombie Boy for his head-to-toe tattoos, modeling clothing by the designer Thierry Mugler in 2011 in Paris.
item.description: Mr. Genest, whose tattoos covered his entire body, participated in the 2011 Lady Gaga music video “Born This Way.”
item.dc:creator: AMISHA PADNANI

item.title: Pompeo Says There’s ‘a Ways to Go’ Before North Korea Fulfills Nuclear Vows
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo delivering his opening address during the ASEAN-U.S. Ministerial Meeting in Singapore on Friday.
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is urging Asian allies to keep pressuring North Korea with economic sanctions.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: A Sunflower Farm Invited Tourists. It Ended Up Like a ‘Zombie Apocalypse.’
item.media:description: Brad Bogle, left, and his father, Barry Bogle, standing in their sunflower field in Hamilton, Ont. They were forced to close their farm to visitors last weekend after selfie-taking tourists crowded roads.
item.description: The owners of a Canadian seed farm were forced to close to visitors last weekend after selfie-taking tourists overwhelmed the farm and nearby roads with traffic.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Star Athlete Is Injured in Egg Attack, and Italy Debates ‘a Racism Emergency’
item.media:description: The Italian discus thrower Daisy Osakue addressed the media outside the hospital in Turin on Monday after she was hit in the face by an egg hurled from a car.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Marco/ANSA, via Associated Press
item.description: Daisy Osakue, whose eye was struck in an assault, has become the bandaged face of a question confronting Italy: Is it more racist under the anti-immigrant government?
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Ebola Poses High Risk in Congo, W.H.O. Says
item.media:description: Patients at a health center in May during a vaccination campaign against Ebola in Équateur Province, Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.description: The latest outbreak of the virus is believed to have killed more than 20 people, but the danger of the disease spreading worldwide was said to be low.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Brazil’s Supreme Court Considers Decriminalizing Abortion
item.media:description: Natanael Barbosa and his aunt, Maria Aparecida Barbosa, talking about Natanael’s sister Ingriane Barbosa Carvalho, who died from a clandestine abortion.
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.description: A rare two-day public hearing on abortion comes as legislators are trying to restrict the practice.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: China Threatens New Tariffs on $60 Billion of U.S. Goods
item.media:description: China has threatened new tariffs on a wide array of American goods, the latest sign that a trade dispute between Washington and Beijing is escalating.
item.media:credit: Todd Spoth for The New York Times
item.description: The new threat comes after President Trump asked his administration to consider more than doubling tariffs on $200 billion a year of Chinese goods.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CAO LI

item.title: Attackers in Burqas Kill Dozens at Shiite Mosque in Afghanistan
item.media:description: A damaged Shiite mosque after a suicide attack during Friday prayers in Gardez, Afghanistan.
item.description: Two bombers, wearing women’s clothes to hide explosive vests and automatic weapons, killed at least 29 worshipers during Friday Prayer.
item.dc:creator: FAROOQ JAN MANGAL and FAHIM ABED
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pompeo Warns Turkey on Detained U.S. Pastor: The Clock Has ‘Run Out’
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo discussed the case of the detained pastor with the Turkish foreign minister on the sidelines of a security conference in Singapore.
item.description: The imprisonment of Andrew Brunson prompted sanctions from the Trump administration. But the Turkish foreign minister said harsh tactics would not work.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Japanese Medical School Accused of Rigging Admissions to Keep Women Out
item.media:description: Tokyo Medical University reduced the test scores of women, according to a Japanese newspaper.
item.media:credit: Ayaka Aizawa/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.description: Tokyo Medical University was reported to have secretly skewed test scores out of the belief that women were more likely to drop out of the profession.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and HISAKO UENO

item.title: Australia’s Big Banks Have Stranglehold on Consumers, Government Says
item.media:description: A woman using a Commonwealth Bank A.T.M. in Sydney, Australia. Commonwealth is one of the country’s biggest banks, which received a harsh rebuke in a government report for exploiting customers and other bad behavior.
item.description: The biggest banks used their position to exploit customers and block competition, a new government report says. In some cases, dead people were charged banking fees.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: U.S. Is Expanding Power to Block Chinese Firms. HNA Was Already No Match.
item.media:description: Last year, during HNA Group’s effort to buy SkyBridge Capital, its senior executives met with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin at the department’s headquarters in Washington.
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.description: High-level meetings, powerful lobbying firms and a charm offensive were unable to get regulators to approve a deal with SkyBridge Capital, Anthony Scaramucci’s firm.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

item.title: Myanmar Dispatch: Myanmar Official Line: Rohingya Are Returning. But Cracks in That Story Abound.
item.media:description: Rohingya Muslims seen behind barbed wire in the Taung Pyo border area where they are stranded between Myanmar and Bangladesh.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: On a government-led tour of repatriation centers and the surrounding countryside, the sanctioned narrative grew sticky with contradictions as witnesses spoke up.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Mali’s President Forced Into Runoff Election
item.media:description: President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta of Mali cast his vote at a polling station in Bamako, the capital, on Sunday. He now faces a runoff against his rival, Soumaïla Cissé.
item.description: President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita failed to get enough votes to win a second term outright, according to preliminary figures.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Latest Ebola Outbreak Is Centered in a War Zone
item.media:description: An Ebola security zone where workers disinfected their shoes, in Équateur Province of the Democratic Republic of Congo, in May. The site of the latest Ebola outbreak, North Kivu Province, is plagued by armed conflict.
item.description: Unlike the earlier outbreaks, the epicenter this time is in a part of the Democratic Republic of Congo that is plagued by armed conflict.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Russia, Pope Francis, Apple: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Saudis Escalate Siege of Port in Yemen, Alarming Aid Groups
item.media:description: Airstrikes by a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia killed at least 30 people in Al Hudaydah, Yemen, on Thursday, medical workers said. Relatives of some of the victims gathered in a morgue in the city.
item.description: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition on Al Hudaydah, occupied by Houthi rebels, killed at least 30 people, medical workers said.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD and MARGARET COKER

item.title: Zimbabwe Elects Mnangagwa, the Man Who Ousted Mugabe
item.media:description: President Emmerson Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe after casting his ballot in Kwekwe on Monday.
item.description: Emmerson Mnangagwa, who seized power last year, won a full term over his chief challenger, Nelson Chamisa.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Europe Feels the Squeeze of the Trump Trade Tariffs
item.media:description: Volkswagen, which reported a 7 percent increase in quarterly earnings Wednesday, also warned that trade tensions could become a drag on sales and profit.
item.description: Business managers worry whether a cease-fire between Brussels and the White House will hold. The uncertainty is bad for growth.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: U.K. Court Can Dissolve a Muslim Marriage, Judge Rules
item.media:description: The Royal Courts of Justice in London. A justice ruled on Thursday that the courts could dissolve a religious marriage even if it was never registered with civil authorities.
item.description: The case could be an important step for women. Many Muslim couples have marriages the law does not recognize, so they cannot go to court to divorce.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Sweden’s Tallest Peak Shrinks in Record Heat
item.media:description: Gunhild Rosqvist, a Stockholm University geography professor, making measurements atop the southern tip of Kebnekaise, formerly Sweden’s highest peak.
item.media:credit: Carl Lundberg/Stockholm University, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Soaring temperatures are melting snow and ice from Kebnekaise’s southern peak, making the northern part of the mountain Sweden’s highest point.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: 3 Foreign Caterers Are Kidnapped and Killed in Afghanistan
item.media:description: The street in Kabul, Afghanistan, where three foreigners working for the international catering company Sodexo were abducted on Thursday.
item.description: Food service workers from India, Malaysia and Macedonia were abducted while driving to work in Kabul, and were found shot dead outside the city.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED

item.title: A Hemingway War Story Sees Print for the First Time
item.media:description: Ernest Hemingway surrounded by American soldiers in France, months before Allied troops liberated Paris from the Nazis. A newly published short story, “A Room on the Garden Side,” takes place in Paris shortly after the liberation.
item.description: In 1956, Ernest Hemingway wrote five short stories about World War II, including “A Room on the Garden Side,” saying they could be published after he died. Three remain.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG
item.category: A Room on the Garden Side

item.title: Was It Safe to Go to a Militant’s Funeral?
item.media:description: Kashmiri Muslims carry the body of the militant commander Sameer Ahmed Bhat — “Sameer Tiger” during his funeral procession.
item.description: When an outlawed militant I was covering was killed in battle, I faced a choice: Do I go to his funeral, where there will surely be many very upset people, or not?
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: At War: How the Defense Department Identifies the Remains of Our War Dead
item.media:description: Flag-draped cases with the remains of American soldiers repatriated from North Korea on display during a ceremony in Honolulu on Aug. 1.
item.description: A forensic anthropologist explains how the Defense Department identifies the remains of American service members, like those recently returned from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ISMAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Thousands of Confiscated Coffins and an Exhumed Corpse Stoke Fury in China
item.media:description: Escorting ashes at the Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery in Beijing. The Communist Party’s ideas on “burial reform” have often clashed with traditional practices.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: The authorities in Jiangxi Province acknowledged that local officials had gone overboard in pushing cremations to save land as part of “burial reform” efforts.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Grenfell Tower Is No Longer a Crime Scene, Police Say
item.media:description: The remains of Grenfell Tower, covered in scaffolding and lit in green, loom over West London.
item.description: The future of the charred 24-story apartment block in London where a fire last year killed 72 people will be decided by the local community.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Fields Medal Is Stolen Minutes After It’s Given in Brazil
item.media:description: Caucher Birkar, a professor at the University of Cambridge in England, receiving the Fields Medal in Rio de Janeiro on Wednesday.
item.description: Caucher Birkar, a Cambridge University professor, was one of four winners of the award, which is regarded as the world’s most prestigious prize for math.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: A Chinese Activist Was Challenging Xi on Live TV. The Police Came to Stop Him.
item.description: Sun Wenguang, a rights activist and retired professor, was criticizing President Xi Jinping when police officers barged into his home and cut him off.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: In Maldives, Suspects Are Cleared in Disappearance of Prominent Journalist
item.media:description: Aminath Easa, left, the mother of the journalist Ahmed Rilwan Abdulla, last year. In an interview last year, she said the investigation into his disappearance had never been transparent and that efforts to get information from the police were ignored.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Two men accused of kidnapping Ahmed Rilwan Abdulla, who is still missing, were acquitted. Observers and rights advocates said the trial and investigation were a sham.
item.dc:creator: HASSAN MOOSA and KAI SCHULTZ
